A group of pharmacists is studying different types of antagonism in the laboratory. While studying, they found that 2 different drugs act on 2 different sites in the same cell, and their response is opposite to each other . This drug reaction may be seen in which type of antagonism?
questions.explanation:
Type of Antagonism Mechanism Example
Competitive Antagonism Antagonist competes with agonist for receptor binding site, reducing agonist's effect Naloxone blocks opioid receptors, reversing the effects of opioids
Non-competitive Antagonism Antagonist binds to a different site on the receptor or a different target in the signaling pathway, inhibiting agonist's action Phenoxybenzamine irreversibly binds to alpha-adrenergic receptors, blocking the activation by norepinephrine
Physiological Antagonism Two substances exert opposing physiological effects through different mechanisms Histamine causes vasodilation, while epinephrine causes vasoconstriction, resulting in physiological antagonism
Chemical Antagonism Antagonist interacts with another substance, rendering it inactive through a chemical reaction Chelating agents like EDTA bind to heavy metals, forming stable complexes and reducing their toxic effects

questions.text: If the fetus is born dead at 5 months, the signs of which one of the following is not identifiable during autopsy?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Signs of Dead-Born Fetus:
  • ➤ Signs of Dead-Born Fetus:
  • ➤ Maceration: It is a process of aseptic autolysis. It occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about 3–4 days surrounded with liquor amnii with exclusion of air. Rigor mortis: It is claimed that rigor mortis does not occur in fetuses of < 7 months old (there are only few muscle fibers and cannot contribute to appreciable degree of stiffness). Mummification: It results from deficient supply of blood or scanty liquor amnii. The fetus is dried up and shriveled in ≥ 2 weeks. Spalding’s sign: A pathognomic sign of intra-uterine death. There is loss of alignment and overlapping of fetal skull bones on X-ray, which occurs due to liquefaction of cerebrum and softening of ligamentous structures supporting the vault. It appears in about 7 days after death. Robert’s sign: Appearance of gas shadow in chambers of heart and great vessels, may appear by 12 h, but difficult to interpret.
  • ➤ Maceration: It is a process of aseptic autolysis. It occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about 3–4 days surrounded with liquor amnii with exclusion of air.
  • ➤ It occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about 3–4 days surrounded with liquor amnii with exclusion of air.
  • ➤ It occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about 3–4 days surrounded with liquor amnii with exclusion of air.
  • ➤ Rigor mortis: It is claimed that rigor mortis does not occur in fetuses of < 7 months old (there are only few muscle fibers and cannot contribute to appreciable degree of stiffness).
  • ➤ Mummification: It results from deficient supply of blood or scanty liquor amnii. The fetus is dried up and shriveled in ≥ 2 weeks.
  • ➤ Spalding’s sign: A pathognomic sign of intra-uterine death. There is loss of alignment and overlapping of fetal skull bones on X-ray, which occurs due to liquefaction of cerebrum and softening of ligamentous structures supporting the vault. It appears in about 7 days after death.

questions.explanation:
Allelic heterogeneity Different mutations in the same genetic locus can cause an identical or similar phenotype. eg- different mutations of the β-globin locus- β-thalassemia
Phenotypic Heterogeneity When more than one phenotype is caused by allelic mutations e.g. Identical mutations in the FGFR2 gene- Crouzon syndrome or Pfeiffer syndrome
Locus or Non-allelic Heterogeneity Similar disease phenotype results from mutations at different genetic loci. eg- osteogenesis imperfecta- mutations in COL1A1 or COL 1A2: located on different chromosomes

questions.text: Consider the following statements and choose the correct answer? Statement 1:-Fluid restriction and not medication is the best for management of asymptomatic hyponatremia with serum Sodium less than 120 mEq/L, in patients of cirrhosis with oedema. Statement 2 :- Conivaptan decreases B.P. and increases risk of variceal bleeding and so relatively contraindicated in cirrhotics with hyponatremia.

options.label: A
options.text: Statement 1 is wrong and Statement 2 is correct

options.label: D
options.text: Statement 1 is correct and Statement 2 is wrong

questions.explanation:
Fluid restriction and not medication is the best for management of asymptomatic hyponatremia with serum sodium less than 120 mEq/L and in patients of cirrhosis with edema.

Asymptomatic hyponatremia will respond to fluid restriction.

Symptomatic hyponatremia with neurological implications must be corrected at a rate of 4-8mEq/L over 24hours with 3% Hypertonic saline
Conivaptan decreases B.P. and increases risk of variceal bleeding and so relatively contraindicated in cirrhotics with hyponatremia

Conivaptan acts on V IA and V2 receptors. V IA stimulation is associated with vasoconstrictive, mitogenic, and possibly platelet aggregative effects. Conivaptan causes inhibition of VIA receptors and is beneficial for patients with CHF with concomitanthypertension and atherosclerotic disease.

In contrast, the very same effects derived from V IA inhibition can be harmful for hypotensive patients or cirrhotic patients with dilated splanchnic beds and variceal bleeds.

Further dilatation of the splanchnic bed and interference with platelet aggregation by V IA inhibition could exacerbate variceal bleeding.

Physical examination reveals a nontender right abdominal mass His temperature is 37.1°C, BP of 98/68 mmHg, PR 120/min, RR 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Abdominal exam demonstrates a palpable mass limited to the right side of the abdomen. Renal USG shows a heterogeneous mass originating from the right kidney. CT of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following pathologic descriptions represents the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A mutation of the PKD1 gene on chromosome 16

options.label: C
options.text: Malignant proliferation of primitive neural crest cells

options.label: D
options.text: Malignant transformation of renal tubular cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Malignant proliferation of metanephric blastema

questions.text: A 45-year-old multiparous woman presents to the physician with excessive menstrual bleeding with dysmenorrhea associated with backache since a year which has been progressively worsening. On examination, there is no discharge, uterus appears diffusely enlarged and there is no adnexal or uterine tenderness. Ultrasound shows loss on endomyometrial interface. A 55-year-old man with a history of COPD presents to the emergency room with a two-day history of worsening shortness of breath which came on following a recent viral infection. In the emergency room, his oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. He is working hard to breathe and is only speaking in short sentences. Inspiratory pressure <−25 cm H2O
Tidal volume >5 mL/kg
Vital capacity >10 mL/kg
Minute ventilation <10 mL
Rapid shallow breathing index <100

An 18 yrs old, male was brought in with complaints of overeating, increased weight gain having BMI of 41.6 kg/m2 and noted to have mental retardation. He was diagnosed of having adult onset diabetes mellitus. Which of the following endocrine disorder best describes the above clinical scenario?

The eye's lens is a biconvex, relatively acellular, optically transparent intraocular structure that, with the cornea, transmits light to the retina with minimal light scattering. The lens can modify the shape, so that image of the object is focused on the retina. From which of the following embryologic structures is the lens derived?
questions.explanation:
Embryonic layers

Structures derived

Surface ectoderm
  • The crystalline lens
  • Epithelium of the cornea
  • Epithelium of the conjunctiva
  • Lacrimal gland
  • Epithelium of eyelids and its derivatives viz., cilia, tarsal glands, and conjunctival glands.
  • Epithelium lining the lacrimal apparatus.

Neural ectoderm
  • Retina with its pigment epithelium
  • Epithelial layers of the ciliary body
  • Epithelial layers of the iris
  • Sphincter and dilator pupillae muscles
  • Optic nerve (neuroglia and nervous elements only)
  • Melanocytes
  • Secondary vitreous
  • Ciliary zonules (tertiary vitreous)

Associated paraxial mesenchyme
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary vessels, central retinal artery, and other blood vessels.
  • Primary vitreous
  • Substantia propria, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium of the cornea
  • The sclera
  • Stroma of iris
  • Ciliary muscle
  • Sheaths of the optic nerve
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Fat, ligaments, and other connective tissue structures of the orbit

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with 21 weeks of gestation came to gynecology OPD for an antenatal checkup. The doctor decided to check the cardiac valve motion and fetal heart rate of the baby. Which mode of ultrasound is used in this case?

A 30-year-old mother of three children who had no history of mental illness before gave birth to her third child 4 weeks ago. Her pregnancy and labor had been uneventful & as she had delivered baby boy at the general hospital within the city. For the last one week, family and friends noticed a change in her overall mood. She was no longer cheerful and was constantly feeling tired. She had lost interest in her daily and community activities. She became irritable & agitated and was having difficulty sleeping. She became more religious and talked about god and evil obsessively. She also stated that she started to hear God talking to her and that she would need to sacrifice her baby to cleanse the sins of her family.
questions.explanation:
Post-partum psychosis – usually in first 2-3 weeks of post-partum (onset should be <6 weeks postpartum)

  • characterized by the mother’s depression, delusions, and thoughts of harming either herself or her infant
  • It may involve the idea that the baby is dead or defective. Patients may deny the birth and express thoughts of being unmarried, virginal, persecuted, or perverse
  • Some patients may attempt to kill the child to spare it from future suffering.
Post-partum blues - women experience a brief episode of irritability, muddled thinking, tearfulness, and lability of mood, which is particularly characteristic
Post-partum depression - Tiredness, irritability, and anxiety are often more prominent than depressive mood and there may be prominent phobic symptoms.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician's office by her parents for the complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past few weeks. Which of the following treatment is done for Juvenile onset recurrent respiratory papillomatosis?
questions.explanation:
S. No Drug Name Action
1 Interferon-α

(Interferon-alpha)

 a. Interferes with normal host cell translation mechanisms and induces synthesis of intracellular enzymes that act to control viral growth

b. Depletes essential metabolites in papilloma cells and increases the length of their multiplication cycle

c. Facilitates recognition of papilloma cells by circulating leucocytes by enhancing expression of cell surface antigens
2. Bevacizumab Recombinant monoclonal antibody: inhibits angiogenesis (VEGF-A), thereby inhibiting the blood supply of the tumor cells.
3. Cidofovir

(Intralesional)

 Acyclic nucleoside phosphonate: inhibition of viral DNA polymerases
4. Ribarvarin

(aerosol)

 Synthetic nucleoside (broad spectrum antiviral)
5. Acyclovir Nucleoside analog, which inhibits thymidine kinase
6. Indole-3-Carbinol Affects estrogen metabolism shifting production to antiproliferative estrogen
7. Cimetidine Histamine receptor type 2 (H2) antagonist

A 35 years old patient reported to the hospital with skin lesions of 1-month duration. Many of them were accompanied by satellite lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Leprosy Hypopigmented hypo aesthetic plaques with surface showing loss of appendages, dryness and thickened peripheral nerves.
Chronic Fungal infection Varied morphologies with swelling, induration, pus discharge, nasal architectural disruption. Agents like - rhinosporidiosis, mucormycosis, actinomycosis.
Cutaneous tuberculosis Slowly enlarging infiltrated plaque with expanding edge and healing with scarring at other ends.

questions.text: A 28-year-old Lorry driver who was driving for a long distance decided to take a nap, parked his vehicle on the side of the road, and was sleeping under the lorry. Unfortunately, another lorry driver who was driving under the influence of alcohol lost control and hit this lorry on the backside. The patient was brought to the ER after 2 hours of the incident. Proximal limb amputation is planned for this patient. The Sequence of reimplantation is?

options.label: A
options.text: Extensor tendon - Flexor tendon - Bone - Nerves - Veins - Arteries - Skin

options.label: B
options.text: Bone - Extensor tendon - Flexor tendon - Arteries - Nerves - Veins - Skin

options.label: C
options.text: Bone - Flexor tendon - Extensor tendon - Arteries - Veins - Nerves - Skin

options.label: D
options.text: Bone - Arteries - Nerves - Veins - Extensor tendon - Flexor tendon - Skin

questions.correct_answer: B. Bone - Extensor tendon - Flexor tendon - Arteries - Nerves - Veins - Skin
questions.explanation:
Sequence of reimplantation (Mnemonic: BE FAN VS )
  • B - Bone (first to be implanted)
  • E - Extensor tendon
  • F - Flexor tendon
  • A - Arteries
  • N - Nerves
  • V - Veins
  • S - Skin (preserved first implanted last)
